text: <@U0TFEHX8E|sheehan> set the channel purpose: Weekly review of outstanding PRs

My understanding is that the creation of this channel was discussed at the last fabric maintainers meeting. Unfortunately I was not able to attend so feel free to fill me in on any missed details

We should use this channel to get together once per week (Wednesday at 10am EDT?) and address at least 5 outstanding PRs. For each PR we should either merge, close, or comment. Hopefully this will help unstick some PRs and make sure they’re not in limbo for too long
For our first set, I’d like to nominate 1719, 1721, and 1722 for discussion. Let me know if there are any other you’d like to put on the list for consideration
we should send this channel to the hyperledger-fabric mailing list
NB I think that we should be using this just for the immediate discussion and then someone should report any findings to the mailing list
it would be a shame to lose the findings to archiving, especially given how large this slack is- things roll off quickly
overall, I think that protracted discussions should be done on email per Brian’s suggestion and.or in the comments
i agree that is a good set to take care of <@U0TFEHX8E>

Thanks <@U0KM61BCP> for that note; I have to agree, there are so many slack channels here that it can be confusing for new developers to come up to speed on what's happening where.  I would urge you not to have more and more slack channels for particular functions, and not to use slack channels for making project decisions.  The mailing lists are designed for this, are real-time, and afford participation by those who can't all be at the same place at the same time.  I appreciate the urgency to address and close outstanding PRs, that's great, but it shouldn't have to wait for a particular hour of the week.

e.g. I would have taken <@U0MT4CBHB> 's post yesterday and PR by PR, if it covered parts of the code I'm familiar with, I would have either commented and given it support or criticism.  A separate thread per PR would be even better, as that would make for easier threading in the archives and in our mail clients.
Also, there is no graceful cross-posting tool between Slack and mailing lists, because the mode of communication is so different between them.

All good IMHO to use Slack as a tool to help explore an issue, understand a defect or architecture better, help each other through the code.  But anything decisional should be done on the lists, and presume that there are lots more smart people outside the room and outside the time zone who would have something valuable to contribute.

One last thing - I did see that there is commentary on each PR within the comments on it - I think that's great!  Maybe what's needed is some way to get a signal from enough of a critical mass of developers to go forward with the merge; and in the case of Tamas's code, accept the pull request himself.  On Apache in the early days we tended to use "three +1's, and no vetos", meaning so long as you could point to support from three other people (ideally not co-workers but we can roll with that for now) and no other developer stepping up to object to the change, then you could proceed to commit the change.  Perhaps that would be enough to do it no.
to do it now, I mean.
I'll post something along these lines on the fabric list
